trans-unit.source: Code Sample: WordPress Plugin
trans-unit.target: Code Sample: WordPress Plugin

trans-unit.source: Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure

trans-unit.source: Code Sample: WordPress Plugin
trans-unit.target: Code Sample: WordPress Plugin

trans-unit.source: The <token>secondref_acs</token> WordPress Plugin allows WordPress hosts to use <token>secondref_acs</token> to enable federated login for their WordPress sites.
trans-unit.target: The <token>secondref_acs</token> WordPress Plugin allows WordPress hosts to use <token>secondref_acs</token> to enable federated login for their WordPress sites.

trans-unit.source: WordPress administrators can use <token>firstref_acs</token> to create trust relationships between their sites and identity providers such as <token>windows_live_id</token>, Facebook, Google, Yahoo!, and custom identity providers such as Microsoft Active Directory Federation Services 2.0.
trans-unit.target: WordPress administrators can use <token>firstref_acs</token> to create trust relationships between their sites and identity providers such as <token>windows_live_id</token>, Facebook, Google, Yahoo!, and custom identity providers such as Microsoft Active Directory Federation Services 2.0.

trans-unit.source: The <token>secondref_acs</token> WordPress Plugin renders a custom login page based on the <token>secondref_acs</token> configuration and enables end users to use an identify provider of their choice to log in to the WordPress site.
trans-unit.target: The <token>secondref_acs</token> WordPress Plugin renders a custom login page based on the <token>secondref_acs</token> configuration and enables end users to use an identify provider of their choice to log in to the WordPress site.

trans-unit.source: To download the WordPress plugin, see <externalLink><linkText>http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/acs-plugin-for-wordpress/</linkText><linkUri>http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/acs-plugin-for-wordpress/</linkUri></externalLink>
trans-unit.target: To download the WordPress plugin, see <externalLink><linkText>http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/acs-plugin-for-wordpress/</linkText><linkUri>http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/acs-plugin-for-wordpress/</linkUri></externalLink>

trans-unit.source: Features
trans-unit.target: Features

trans-unit.source: Authenticate to WordPress by using <token>windows_live_id</token>, Facebook, Google, Yahoo!, or a custom web-based identity providers configured in <token>secondref_acs</token>
trans-unit.target: Authenticate to WordPress by using <token>windows_live_id</token>, Facebook, Google, Yahoo!, or a custom web-based identity providers configured in <token>secondref_acs</token>

trans-unit.source: Easy registration for WordPress site subscribers
trans-unit.target: Easy registration for WordPress site subscribers

trans-unit.source: Manage the WordPress site using a federated account
trans-unit.target: Manage the WordPress site using a federated account

trans-unit.source: Federated accounts are identical to normal user accounts and support fallback to local password-based authentication
trans-unit.target: Federated accounts are identical to normal user accounts and support fallback to local password-based authentication

trans-unit.source: Integrates with <token>secondref_acs</token> using the WS-Federation protocol and Simple Web Tokens
trans-unit.target: Integrates with <token>secondref_acs</token> using the WS-Federation protocol and Simple Web Tokens

trans-unit.source: Requirements
trans-unit.target: Requirements

trans-unit.source: A <token>azure_1</token> account at the Azure homepage.
trans-unit.target: A <token>azure_1</token> account at the Azure homepage.

trans-unit.source: An <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.
trans-unit.target: An <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link xlink:href="dba0b42b-c631-4f60-bb3a-7b84d2ac406f" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How to: Create or Modify an Azure ACS Service Namespace</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link xlink:href="dba0b42b-c631-4f60-bb3a-7b84d2ac406f" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How to: Create or Modify an Azure ACS Service Namespace</link>.

trans-unit.source: Web host running PHP 5.0 or later
trans-unit.target: Web host running PHP 5.0 or later

trans-unit.source: Web host running WordPress 3.0 or later
trans-unit.target: Web host running WordPress 3.0 or later

trans-unit.source: Configuring the <token>secondref_acs</token> WordPress Plugin
trans-unit.target: Configuring the <token>secondref_acs</token> WordPress Plugin

trans-unit.source: There are three parts of configuring the <token>secondref_acs</token> WordPress Plugin:
trans-unit.target: There are three parts of configuring the <token>secondref_acs</token> WordPress Plugin:

trans-unit.source: Configuring <token>secondref_acs</token> for the WordPress Plugin
trans-unit.target: Configuring <token>secondref_acs</token> for the WordPress Plugin

trans-unit.source: Configuring the WordPress Plugin settings
trans-unit.target: Configuring the WordPress Plugin settings

trans-unit.source: Enabling the WordPress Plugin
trans-unit.target: Enabling the WordPress Plugin

trans-unit.source: Configuring <token>secondref_acs</token> for the WordPress Plugin
trans-unit.target: Configuring <token>secondref_acs</token> for the WordPress Plugin

trans-unit.source: You can use the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal to configure <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: You can use the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal to configure <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: To configure <token>secondref_acs</token> for the WordPress plugin
trans-unit.target: To configure <token>secondref_acs</token> for the WordPress plugin

trans-unit.source: This action opens the Access Control Service management portal.
trans-unit.target: This action opens the Access Control Service management portal.

trans-unit.source: To establish relationships with the identity providers you would like the users of your website to use when logging in, click <ui>Identity providers</ui> and then select an identity provider for your site.
trans-unit.target: To establish relationships with the identity providers you would like the users of your website to use when logging in, click <ui>Identity providers</ui> and then select an identity provider for your site.

trans-unit.source: To register your WordPress site with <token>secondref_acs</token>, click <ui>Relying party applications</ui>, click <ui>Add</ui>, enter the following information in the form, and then click <ui>Save</ui>.
trans-unit.target: To register your WordPress site with <token>secondref_acs</token>, click <ui>Relying party applications</ui>, click <ui>Add</ui>, enter the following information in the form, and then click <ui>Save</ui>.

trans-unit.source: In the <ui>Name</ui> field, enter a display name for your site.
trans-unit.target: In the <ui>Name</ui> field, enter a display name for your site.

trans-unit.source: In the <ui>Realm</ui> field, enter the base URL of your WordPress site.
trans-unit.target: In the <ui>Realm</ui> field, enter the base URL of your WordPress site.

trans-unit.source: For example: <ui>http://127.0.0.1/wordpress/</ui>
trans-unit.target: For example: <ui>http://127.0.0.1/wordpress/</ui>

trans-unit.source: In the <ui>Return URL</ui> field, enter the URL to the wp-login.php file in your WordPress site.
trans-unit.target: In the <ui>Return URL</ui> field, enter the URL to the wp-login.php file in your WordPress site.

trans-unit.source: For example: <ui>http://127.0.0.1/wordpress/wp-login.php</ui>
trans-unit.target: For example: <ui>http://127.0.0.1/wordpress/wp-login.php</ui>

trans-unit.source: In the <ui>Token Format</ui> field, select <ui>SWT</ui>.
trans-unit.target: In the <ui>Token Format</ui> field, select <ui>SWT</ui>.

trans-unit.source: This configures <token>secondref_acs</token> to send a Simple Web Token (SWT) to the WordPress plugin whenever a user successfully authenticates.
trans-unit.target: This configures <token>secondref_acs</token> to send a Simple Web Token (SWT) to the WordPress plugin whenever a user successfully authenticates.

trans-unit.source: In the <ui>Identity Providers</ui> field, select the identity providers that you want to support on your site.
trans-unit.target: In the <ui>Identity Providers</ui> field, select the identity providers that you want to support on your site.

trans-unit.source: In the <ui>Token Signing Key</ui> field, click <ui>Generate</ui> to create a token signing key.
trans-unit.target: In the <ui>Token Signing Key</ui> field, click <ui>Generate</ui> to create a token signing key.

trans-unit.source: Copy this key for use later in the plugin configuration.
trans-unit.target: Copy this key for use later in the plugin configuration.

trans-unit.source: In the <ui>Expiration Date</ui> field, enter an appropriate expiration date for the key.
trans-unit.target: In the <ui>Expiration Date</ui> field, enter an appropriate expiration date for the key.

trans-unit.source: The key will no longer be valid on this date
trans-unit.target: The key will no longer be valid on this date

trans-unit.source: Leave the other fields at their default values.
trans-unit.target: Leave the other fields at their default values.

trans-unit.source: Next, create the rules that determine the user information that <token>secondref_acs</token> sends to your site.
trans-unit.target: Next, create the rules that determine the user information that <token>secondref_acs</token> sends to your site.

trans-unit.source: In this example, we send all claims issued by the identity providers.
trans-unit.target: In this example, we send all claims issued by the identity providers.

trans-unit.source: To create this rule, click <ui>Rule groups</ui>, click <ui>Default Rule Group for My WordPress Site</ui>, and then click <ui>Generate</ui>.
trans-unit.target: To create this rule, click <ui>Rule groups</ui>, click <ui>Default Rule Group for My WordPress Site</ui>, and then click <ui>Generate</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Verify that your identity providers are selected and click <ui>Generate</ui> again.
trans-unit.target: Verify that your identity providers are selected and click <ui>Generate</ui> again.

trans-unit.source: It is critically important that the input claim type uniquely identifies the user.
trans-unit.target: It is critically important that the input claim type uniquely identifies the user.

trans-unit.source: If you are not sure which claim type to use, contact the administrator of your identity provider.
trans-unit.target: If you are not sure which claim type to use, contact the administrator of your identity provider.

trans-unit.source: If you are using a custom WS-Federation identity provider, such as AD FS 2.0, ensure that there is a rule that returns a <system>nameidentifier</system> claim from this identity provider.
trans-unit.target: If you are using a custom WS-Federation identity provider, such as AD FS 2.0, ensure that there is a rule that returns a <system>nameidentifier</system> claim from this identity provider.

trans-unit.source: This claim sends the unique ID of the user to the WordPress application.
trans-unit.target: This claim sends the unique ID of the user to the WordPress application.

trans-unit.source: If this rule is absent, you must create a rule that maps the unique ID claim returned by that identity provider to the nameidentifier claim type.
trans-unit.target: If this rule is absent, you must create a rule that maps the unique ID claim returned by that identity provider to the nameidentifier claim type.

trans-unit.source: Configuring the WordPress Plugin Settings
trans-unit.target: Configuring the WordPress Plugin Settings

trans-unit.source: To configure the WordPress plugin settings
trans-unit.target: To configure the WordPress plugin settings

trans-unit.source: Download the WordPress Plugin from the WordPress site at <externalLink><linkText>http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/acs-plugin-for-wordpress/</linkText><linkUri>http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/acs-plugin-for-wordpress/</linkUri></externalLink>
trans-unit.target: Download the WordPress Plugin from the WordPress site at <externalLink><linkText>http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/acs-plugin-for-wordpress/</linkText><linkUri>http://wordpress.org/extend/plugins/acs-plugin-for-wordpress/</linkUri></externalLink>

trans-unit.source: Open the <ui>acs-wp-plugin-config-sample.php</ui> file in the downloaded folder.
trans-unit.target: Open the <ui>acs-wp-plugin-config-sample.php</ui> file in the downloaded folder.

trans-unit.source: In the <ui>ACS_NAMESPACE</ui> field, enter the full-qualified domain name of your <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>, such as <ui>mynamespace.accesscontrol.windows.net</ui>.
trans-unit.target: In the <ui>ACS_NAMESPACE</ui> field, enter the full-qualified domain name of your <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>, such as <ui>mynamespace.accesscontrol.windows.net</ui>.

trans-unit.source: To find the domain name, in the <token>secondref_acs</token> portal, click <ui>Application integration</ui>.
trans-unit.target: To find the domain name, in the <token>secondref_acs</token> portal, click <ui>Application integration</ui>.

trans-unit.source: The value appears in the <ui>Management Portal</ui> field of the <ui>Endpoint Reference</ui> section.
trans-unit.target: The value appears in the <ui>Management Portal</ui> field of the <ui>Endpoint Reference</ui> section.

trans-unit.source: For the <ui>ACS_APPLICATION_REALM</ui> constant, enter the realm that you entered when you registered your WordPress site with <token>secondref_acs</token> as a relying party application, for example, <ui>http://127.0.0.1/wordpress/</ui>.
trans-unit.target: For the <ui>ACS_APPLICATION_REALM</ui> constant, enter the realm that you entered when you registered your WordPress site with <token>secondref_acs</token> as a relying party application, for example, <ui>http://127.0.0.1/wordpress/</ui>.

trans-unit.source: In the <ui>ACS_TOKEN_SIGNING_KEY</ui> field, enter the token signing key that you created when you registered your WordPress site as a relying party application.
trans-unit.target: In the <ui>ACS_TOKEN_SIGNING_KEY</ui> field, enter the token signing key that you created when you registered your WordPress site as a relying party application.

trans-unit.source: Treat this key in a secure manner, as you would a password.
trans-unit.target: Treat this key in a secure manner, as you would a password.

trans-unit.source: Save the file as <ui>acs-wp-plugin-config.php</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Save the file as <ui>acs-wp-plugin-config.php</ui>.

trans-unit.source: The acs-wp-plugin-config.php file contains sensitive information that must be protected from unauthorized users.
trans-unit.target: The acs-wp-plugin-config.php file contains sensitive information that must be protected from unauthorized users.

trans-unit.source: We recommend that you set appropriate permissions on this file and configure your web server to deny direct access to this file via the browser.
trans-unit.target: We recommend that you set appropriate permissions on this file and configure your web server to deny direct access to this file via the browser.

trans-unit.source: For Apache web servers, copy the code below into a file named <ui>.htaccess</ui> and place it in the same directory as the acs-wp-plugin-config.php file.
trans-unit.target: For Apache web servers, copy the code below into a file named <ui>.htaccess</ui> and place it in the same directory as the acs-wp-plugin-config.php file.

trans-unit.source: Enabling the WordPress Plugin
trans-unit.target: Enabling the WordPress Plugin

trans-unit.source: To enable the WordPress plugin
trans-unit.target: To enable the WordPress plugin

trans-unit.source: Copy the <ui>acs-plugin-for-wordpress</ui> folder to the <ui>/wp-content/plugins/</ui> folder in your WordPress installation.
trans-unit.target: Copy the <ui>acs-plugin-for-wordpress</ui> folder to the <ui>/wp-content/plugins/</ui> folder in your WordPress installation.

trans-unit.source: In a web browser, navigate to your WordPress site and log in as an administrator.
trans-unit.target: In a web browser, navigate to your WordPress site and log in as an administrator.

trans-unit.source: In the site administration area, click <ui>Plugins</ui>.
trans-unit.target: In the site administration area, click <ui>Plugins</ui>.

trans-unit.source: The <token>secondref_acs</token> Plugin for WordPress page appears.
trans-unit.target: The <token>secondref_acs</token> Plugin for WordPress page appears.

trans-unit.source: Under <ui>ACS Plugin for WordPress</ui>, click <ui>Activate</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Under <ui>ACS Plugin for WordPress</ui>, click <ui>Activate</ui>.

trans-unit.source: The <token>secondref_acs</token> WordPress plugin is now enabled on your site.
trans-unit.target: The <token>secondref_acs</token> WordPress plugin is now enabled on your site.

trans-unit.source: Testing the WordPress Plugin
trans-unit.target: Testing the WordPress Plugin

trans-unit.source: To test the WordPress plugin
trans-unit.target: To test the WordPress plugin

trans-unit.source: To test the plugin, log out of your WordPress site and select <ui>Log in</ui> on the main page of the site.
trans-unit.target: To test the plugin, log out of your WordPress site and select <ui>Log in</ui> on the main page of the site.

trans-unit.source: The login page displays one button for each identity provider that you configured in <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: The login page displays one button for each identity provider that you configured in <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: Select an identity provider and log in..
trans-unit.target: Select an identity provider and log in..

trans-unit.source: When you are authenticated, you will be asked to create a user name for the WordPress site.
trans-unit.target: When you are authenticated, you will be asked to create a user name for the WordPress site.

trans-unit.source: If you logged in using <token>windows_live_id</token>, you will also be asked to enter an e-mail address.
trans-unit.target: If you logged in using <token>windows_live_id</token>, you will also be asked to enter an e-mail address.

trans-unit.source: A new WordPress account with the <ui>Subscriber</ui> role is created and you are redirected to your WordPress profile page.
trans-unit.target: A new WordPress account with the <ui>Subscriber</ui> role is created and you are redirected to your WordPress profile page.

trans-unit.source: For subsequent visits, click the identity provider to log in.
trans-unit.target: For subsequent visits, click the identity provider to log in.

trans-unit.source: You will not be prompted to enter a user name or email address.
trans-unit.target: You will not be prompted to enter a user name or email address.

trans-unit.source: An administrator account can promote federated subscriber accounts to administrator status, so you use a federated account to administer the site.
trans-unit.target: An administrator account can promote federated subscriber accounts to administrator status, so you use a federated account to administer the site.

trans-unit.source: Notes
trans-unit.target: Notes

trans-unit.source: The unique ID that <token>windows_live_id</token> creates for each user is specific to your <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.
trans-unit.target: The unique ID that <token>windows_live_id</token> creates for each user is specific to your <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>.

trans-unit.source: If you replace your <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> with an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> that has a different name, users who authenticated with a <token>windows_live_id</token> account cannot log in to your site.
trans-unit.target: If you replace your <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> with an <token>ad_acs_namespace</token> that has a different name, users who authenticated with a <token>windows_live_id</token> account cannot log in to your site.

trans-unit.source: In the unlikely event that you need to change the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>, these users can still use the WordPress password reset feature to sign in using a local password.
trans-unit.target: In the unlikely event that you need to change the <token>ad_acs_namespace</token>, these users can still use the WordPress password reset feature to sign in using a local password.
